ſacred maiesties humble loyall ſeruant iohn florio avgvsta maesta di anna serenma ▪ regina inghilterra di scotia di francia irlanda c c ſi può dir di voi ſomma regina che non ſia detto delle più lodate di magnanimità ʋirtù beltate incomparabile sopradiuina anzi che ſtile tanto ſi raffina che non ſia vinto dalla maeſtate l altezza la chiarezza la bontate alla qual ogni cuor dicuor inchina la qual di tutti honoril ſpecchio mostra la qual il pregio sour tutte tiene anna l anello della gioia nostra la nostra ſicurtà la nostra ſpene vien dall eccelso la grandezza voſtra dalla grandezza example hardieſt amongſt men ſo gracious vanquiſhed alexander great many ſtrange difficulty forcing citie gaza encountred chaunce betis commanded therein whoſe valour ſiege hee felt woonderfull ſtrange exploites beeing alone forſaken follower armes allbroken allbeſmeared blood wound fighting amongſt number macedonian pellmell laid ſtill vpon provoked ſo deere victorie among miſhappes hee newly received two hurt body ſaid thus vnto betis thou ſhalt die thou wouldest make account thou muſt indure torment may poſſibly bee deviſed inflicted vpon caitife wretch thou art enemy threates eaged plato follow thy buſineſſe know thy ſelfe theſe two member doth generally imply duty likewiſe enfolds companion ſhould buſineſſe might perceive firſt leſſon know convenient knoweth himſelfe take anothers matter owne thing loveth correcteth himſelfe rejecteth ſuperfluous occupation idle imagination vnprofitable propoſitions grant follie deſireth nowhit ſatisfied ſo wiſedome content preſent never diſpleaſed ſelfe epicurus doth diſpenſe age touching foreſight care ſhall inſue amongſt lawes regard deceaſed tie action prince examined dead ſeemes verie ſolide companion maſters lawes juſtice could work head reaſon effect vpon reputation good ſucceſſors thing wee many time preferre life cuſtome brings many ſingular commodity vnto nation obſerve deſired good prince cauſe complaine memorie wicked vſed wee owe like obedience ſubjection king reſpects office eſtimation affection wee owe vertue unworthie wee endure patiently conceale vice aid indifferent action commendation long authoritie hath need aſſiſtance ought aſcribed unto politike order commerce ended reaſon ſhould refuſe unfolding felt wrong vnto juſtice libertie ſpecially refuſe good ſubjects glory reverently faithfully ſerved maſter whoſe imperfection ſo well knowne unto exempting poſteritie ſo profitable example ſuch reſpect ſome private benefite intereſt wickedly imbrace memorie vnwoorthie prince doe particular juſtice charge publike juſtice titus liuius ſpeaketh truely ſaith ſpeech men brought royaltie ever full vaine oſtentations falſe witneſſes every man indifferently extolling king furtheſt ſtraine valour soveraigne greatneſſe magnanimitie thoſe two souldiers may bee reproved one demaunded nero hated anſwered teeth loved thee whileſt thou waſt worthie love ſince thou becameſt parricide firbrand juglar minde ſo well purified continuall exerciſe wiſedome vertue ſo wel prepared likely inclination though raſh inconſiderate ever great moment woorthie followed every man feeleth himſelfe ſome image ſuch agitation prompt vehement caſuall opinion give ſome authoritie affoord ſo little wiſedome ſome equally weake reaſon violent perſwaſion diſſwaſion ordinarie socrates ſo happily ſo profitably ſuffred inconvenience threatenvs conſequence feare ſhould ſurpriſevs contrariwiſe honeſt meanes man warrant himſelfe evil onely tolerable commendable part conſtancie chiefly acted firmely bearing inconvenience againſt remedie ſound nimbleneſſe bodie wealding handweapons reject may ſort defendvs blow meant atvs many moſt warlike nation conflict fight vſed retreating flight principall advantage ſhewed back enemie much dangerouſly face turkes day retaine ſomething humour socrates plato doth mocke laches becauſe defined fortitude keepe herſelfe ſteadie rancke againſt enemy ſaith hee cowardiſe beate giving place alleadgeth homer againſt commendeth aencas skill flying giving ground becauſe laches better adviſed avoweth cuſtome amongſt scithians generally amongſt horſemen alleageth unto example lacedemonian footman nation vſed fight foote battell plateae unable open put rowt perſian phalanx adviſed themſelves ſcatter put themſelves backe ſo opinion flght might ſhould purſue ruſh upon put ſo combinedmaſſe rout meanes gained victorie touching scithians reported darius went ſubdue ſent king many reprochfull ſpeeches ſo much hee ever ſaw retire giue ground avoide maine battell indathirſez ſo name anſwered feare man living faſhion nation march thus neither city houſes manured land defend feare enemy ſhould reape commoditie hee ſo great deſire feede might draw neerer view place ancient sepulcher hee ſhould meete ſpeake bellyfull notwithſtanding man within reach cannonſhot pointblancke fortune warre doth diverſe time bring men unto ill beſeemeth reſolute minde wiſe peripatetike doth exempt himſelfe perturbation mind doth moderate thirteenth chapter ceremony enterview king ſubject ſo vaine deſerveth place rapſodie notable diſcourteſie vnto common rule towards equall toward great perſon meete houſe warned come margaret queene navarre woont ſay purpoſe kinde incivilitie gentleman depart houſe faſhion meete comming worthy ſoever agreeth civilitie reſpect ſtay home entertaine except feare ſtranger ſhould miſſe way ſuffioeth companie waite vpon going away againe oftentimes forget theſe vaine office one endevoureth aboliſh maner ceremony houſe bee offended doe withall rather offend ſtranger ſelfe everie day continuall ſubjection end doe men avoid ſervitude court entertaine ſame owne houſes moreover common rule aſſemblies hee meaner man may rightly deeme himſelfe happie till ſuch time paſſed laſt day life reaſon vncertaintie viciſſitude humane thing light motive ſlight occaſion often changed one another cleane contrary ſtate degree therefore ageſilaus anſwered one counted king perſia happy becauſe yong gotten garland ſo mightie great dominion yea ſaid priame ſame age vnhappy king macedon ſucceeded alexander great ſome afterward ſeene become ioyners scrivener rome tirants sicilie schoolemaſters corinth one conquered halfe world emperour ſo many army became humble miſerable ſuter raskally officer king aegypt ſo high rate great pompey purchaſe irkeſome prolonging life five ſix moneths father day lodowicke sforce tenth duke millane vnder ſtate italie ſo long beene turmoiled ſhaken ſeene die wretched priſoner loch france till lived lingered ten yeares thraldome worſt bargaine faireſt queene wife greateſt king chriſtendome ſhe lately ſeene die hand executioner oh vnworthie barbarous crueltie thouſand ſuch example ſeemeth 43 obterit pulchros faſces ſaváſque ſecures proculcare ac ludibrio ſibi habere videtur hidden power ſo men ſtates hath worne faire ſwordes fierce ſcepters ſignes honour borne ſeemes trample deride ſcorne ſeemeth fortune doth ſometimes narrowly watch laſt day life thereby ſhew power one moment overthrow many yeares together ſhe beene erecting make v crie laberius nimirum hac die vna plus vixi mihi quàm vivendum fuit thus lived longer one day ſhould may good adviſe solon taken reaſon ſomuch hee philoſopher favour disfavour fortune good ill lucke place regarded puiſſances greatneſſes accident qualitie well nigh indifferent deeme likely reach meant ſame good fortune life dependeth tranquilitie contentment welborne minde reſolution aſſurance well ordered ſoule ſhould never aſcribed vnto man vntill beene ſeene play laſt act comedie without doubt hardeſt reſt may beſome maske either theſe ſophiſticall diſcourſes philoſophie v countenance accident never touch v quick give v alwaies eſt nothing moved cut firſt place allowable yet ſeemeth may ſpeake boldely argueth great ſelfelove preſumption man eſteeme opinion ſo far eſtabliſh man muſt faine ſubvert publike peace introduce ſo conteſted debatable error worſe kinde vice thoſe ſhocke man owne conſcience naturall knowledge senate durſt give defeate payment controverſies betweene people myſterie religion ad deos id magi quàm ad ſe pertinere ipſos viſuros ne ſacra ſuapolluantur rather belong god god ſhould looke due rite polluted greeing oracle anſwered thoſe delphos▪ median warre fearing inuaſions perſians demaunded god ſhould doe treaſures conſecrated temple whether hide cary away anſwered ſhould remove nothing take care themſelves able provide thing fit chriſtian religion hath markes extreame juſtice profit none apparant exact commendation obedience due vnto magiſtrates manutention policy wonderfull example hath divine wiſedome left v eſtabliſh wellfare humane kinde conduct glorious victorie againſt death ſinne would mercy politik order hath ſubmitted progreſſe conduct ſo high worthie effect blindneſſe injuſtice obſervations cuſtomes ſuffering innocentbloud ſo many favored elect runne allowing long defect hath part moderation hath exceſſe much worſe caſe medleth chuſing changing vſurpeth authoritie judging muſt reſolve himſelfe ſee fault hunteth good bringeth ſo vulgar conſideration hath confirmed ſtate reſtrained youth raſh burthening ſhoulders ſo filthie burthen make ſelfe reſpondent ſo important ſcience dare ſound judgement durſt eaſieſt thoſe wherein beene inſtructed wherein raſhnes judging prejudice seeming moſt impious goe ſubmit publike conſtitutions vnmoveable obſervances inſtabilitie private fantaſie private reaſon private juriſdiction vndertake devinelawes policie would tolerate civill law wherein although man reaſon much commerce yet ſoverainly judge judge extreame ſufficiencie ſerveth expound cuſtome extend vſe received divert innovate ſame time devine providence hath gone beyond rule hath neceſſary conſtrained v give v diſpenſation blowes lier divine hand ought imitate admire extraordinarie example markes expreſſe particular avowing ſeverall kind wonder teſtimonie hir omnipotencie offereth v beyond order force follie impictie goe repreſent ought follow contemplate admiration meditate aſtoniſhment act hir perſonage co • ta proteſteth opportunely quum de religione agitur coruncanum p seipionem p scaeuolam pontifex ci • de nat l 3 p maximos non zenonem aut cleanthem aut chryſippum ſequor talke religion follow titus coruncanus enflamed exaſperated ſharpned hir conflict ſtill remaine body could reaſon hir weakneſſe purge v hath rather weakned v ſo cannot voide operation reap nothing long continuall inteſtine griefes ache yet fortune ever reſerving hir authoritie diſcourſes doth ſomtimes preſent v vrgent neceſſitie lawes muſt needes yeeld hir ſome place man reſiſteth increaſe innovation brought violence keepe himſelfe eachwhere altogether rule bridle againſt thoſe keyes field thing lawfull may ſort advance deſſeigne law order follow advantage dangerous obligation prejudiciall inequalitie aditum nocendi perfido praeſtat fidessen oed act 3 ſe • 1 truſt thvntruſtie may hurt make open way ſo much ordinarie diſcipline eſtate hath perfect health doth provide theſe extraordinarie accident preſuppoſeth bodie holding ſelfe principall member office common conſent obſerve obey lawfull proceeding cold dull heauie forced proceeding like hold againſt licentious vnbridled proceeding yet men know reproch thoſe two great perſonages octavius cato civill warres one scilla caeſar becauſe rather ſuffered countrie incur extremity hir lawes aide hir innovate thing truely theſe laſt neceſſities nothing left take hould peradventure better ſhrug ſhoulders ſtoope head ſomewhat yeeld ſtrooke beyond poſſibilitie make head reſiſt nothing better give violence occaſion trample vnderfoote better force lawes deſire may plutarke commendeth philopaemen borne commaund could onely commaund according lawes lawes themſelues whenſoever publike neceſſitie required three twentieth chapter diuers event one ſelfe ſame counſell treacherouſly without cauſe killed goe way withdraw ſelfe let mee never ſee heere againe wiſe henceforward enterpriſes take boneſter men counſellers thoſe religion emperour auguſtus gaule received certaine advertiſement conſpiracie l cinna complotted againſt whereof purpoſed avenged purpoſe ſent friend againſt next morrow adviſe counſell paſſed foregoing night great anxietie vnreſt conſidering following intent ſhould bring yong gentleman well borne noble houſe great pompeyes nephew death perplexitie produced diver ſtrange diſcourſes conſideration ſaid vnto himſelfe shall ever bee reported doe live feare ſuffer mine enemie walke pleaſure libertie shall goe free hath attempted reſolved deprive life ſea land ſaved ſo many civill warres ſo many battels eſtabliſhed vniverſall peace world ſhall abſolved goe vnpuniſhed hath determined murther ſacrifice complot conſpiracie murther ſhould ſacrifice taken ſome reſt himſelfe lowder voice beganne exclaime cry againſt himſelfe ſaying liveſt thou life ſo many depend thy death shall thy vengeance cruelty never end thy life worth may counter vaile ſundry miſchiefes like enſue preſerved livia wife bed perceiving agonie hearing ſpeeches ſaid thus vnto may woman counſels admitted doe phyſitians woont ordinarie receipt worke recourſe contrarie hitherto thou couldeſt never doe good ſeveritie lepidus hath followed savidienus murena lepidus coepio murena egnatius scoepio beginne proove good lenitie clemencie doe thee cinna convicted pardon annoy hurt thee able thou ſhalt thereby encreaſe thy glory auguſtus ſeemed glad found advocate humour thanked wife countermaunded friend ſummoned counſell commaunded cinna brought alone ſending men chamber chaire prepared cinna ſit thus beſpake firſt cinna require gentle audience thou wilt interrupt ſpeech ended give thee time leaſure anſwer thou knoweſt oh cinna taken thee priſoner mine enemy campe wast become borne foe ſaved thee put thee quiet poſſeſſion thy good last ſo enriched thee placed thee ſo high degree even conquerours become envious conquered prieſtes office thou beggedst hand freely beſtowed thee firſt refuſed ſame others whoſe father friendes many battels ſhead bloud benefites dutie tied thee ſo fast vnto thou haſt notwithſtanding vndertaken kill cinna replied cry alowde never ſo much conceived ſo wicked thought much leſſe entertained ſame oh cinna according thy promiſe anſwered auguſtus thou wouldeſt interrupt ſay true thou haſt vndertaken murther ſuch place ſuch day ſuch company ſuch manner ſeeing ſo amazed heart evidence ſtrucken dombe moved thereunto condition promiſe guilt ſelfeaccuſing conſcience wouldeſt thou doe replied becauſe thou wouldeſt emperour truely commonwealth hard condition none ſelfe hinder thee empire • canſt ſo much defend thine hazard potion let nature worke preſuppoſe vnto ſelfe ſhe hath provided ſelfe teeth clawes defend ſelf ſuch aſſaults ſhal beſet maintaine contexture frame whoſe diſſolution ſo much hateth liew bringing poeticall fury raviſh tranſport author beyond himſelfe ſhall aſcribe good fortune ſince himſelfe confeſſeth exceede ſtrength ſufficiencie acknowledgeth proceede elſewhere himſelfe power orator ſay himſelfe continuall daily ſearches every made calling minde ſmall pleaſure might hope ſuch life much better die live ſuch continuall feare agonie himſelfe called voluntarily diſcovered lurking hole might ridde himſelfe purſuite care willingly yeeld vnto crueltie man call enemy aid counſell ſomewhat raſh yet thinke better embrace remaine ſtill continuall fit ſuch feaver hath remedie ſince proviſions man may apply vnto full vnquietneſſe vncertaintie much better full aſſurance prepare himſelfe patiently endure whatſoever may happen draw ſome comfort man never ſure ſhall come paſſe foure drawes deſpiſe conceive according beſt vnderſtanding eſtabliſhed limit truth bound falſehood found muſt neceſſarily beleeve thing wherein ſtrangeneſſe thoſe deny alreadie bound ſelfe abandon thinkes brings much diſorder conſciences namely theſe trouble religion wherin diſpenſation catholikes make beliefe ſuppoſe ſhew themſelves moderate skilfull yeeld adverſaries thoſe article queſtion beſides perceive advantage chargeth begin yeeld give ground much encorageth purſue point thoſe article chuſe lighteſt oftentimes moſt important either man muſt wholy ſubmit himſelfe authoritie eccleſiaſticall downe another pithie materiall conſequence likewiſe produced tender age eight twentieth chapter nine twentie sonnet steven de la boetie ladie grammont counteſſe guiſſen madame preſent nothing mine either becauſe already becauſe finde nothing therein woorthy whereſoever theſe verſes ſhall ſeene honor thereby ſhall redound glorious coriſand • andoms guide thought good adorne woorthie name deemed preſent fit ladiſhip forſomuch lady france either better judge poeſie fitter apply vſe woorthy ſelfe ſince theſe drooping day none give life vigorous ſpirit thoſe rich hightuned accord wherewith amongſt million rar • beauty nature hath richly graced madame theſe verſes deſerve cheriſhed perſwaded mine opinion none come gaskonie either wit better inuention witneſſe proceeded richer vaine let jealouſie poſſeſſe inaſmuch remainder whilome cauſed printed vnder name lord foix woorthy noble deare kinſman truely theſe kinde livelineſſe piercing emphaſis well expreſſe hee made april youth blemiſh reputation religion ſhewing themſelves religious beyond example men qualitie love temperate indifferent nature immoderation towards good offend amazeth troubleth ſhould call neither pauſanias perſwade follow ſo ſavage ſo deare vertue archer overſhootes marke doth otherwiſe ſhooteth ſhort mine eies trouble much climbing vp toward great light goe downe darke caliscles plato ſaith extremitie philoſophie bee hurtfull perſwades man wade bound profit taken moderation pleaſant commodious end make man wilde vicious diſdainfull religion common lawes enemie civill converſation foe humane wile diverts v faire plaine path nature traceth v love beare woman lawfull yet doth divinitie bridle reſtraine ſame remember read saint thomas place condemneth marriage kinsfolkes forbidden degree one reaſon amongſt others love man beareth ſuch woman may immoderate wedlocke husbandlike affection ſound perfect ought alſo ſurcharged man oweth alliance kindred doubt ſurcreaſe may eaſily tranſport like ordinarie fault may well call barbarous regard reaſons rule reſpect v ••• exceed kinde barbariſme warres noble generous much excuſe beautie humane infirmitie may admit ayme nought ſo much foundation amongſt meere jelouſie vertue contend gaining new landes day yet enjoy naturall vbertie fruiteſulneſſe without labouring toyle doth ſuch plenteous aboundance furniſh neceſſary thing neede enlarge limit yet happy eſtate deſire naturall neceſſities direct whatſoever beyond fuperfluous thoſe much one age doe generally entercall one another brother ſuch yoonger call child aged eſteemed father reſt theſe leave full poſſeſſion good common without diviſion heires without claime title nature doth plainely impart vnto creature even ſhee brings world neighbour chance come mountaines aſſaile invade get victory victor conqueſt glorie advantage remaine ſuperior valour vertue elſe nothing doe good ſpoyles vanquiſhed ſo returne countrie neither want neceſſarie thing lacke great port know enioy condition happily contented nature affoord • th doe theſe turne commeth require ranſome priſoners acknowledgement confeſſion vanquiſhed whole age man ſhall finde one doth rather embrace death either word countenance remiſſely yeeld one jot invincible courage none ſeene would rather ſlaine devoured ſue life ſhew feare vſe priſoners libertie may ſo much holde life deare precious commonly entertaine threat future death torment ſhall endure preparation intended purpoſe mangling ſlicing member feaſt ſhall kept charge done wreſt ſome remiſſe exact ſome faintyeelding ſpeech ſubmiſſion poſſeſſe deſire eſcape runne away ſo may advantage danted made afraid forced conſtancie certainly true victory conſiſteth onely point —victoria nulla eſt 〈…〉 quàm quae confeſſos animo quoque ſubingat hoſtes conqueſt ſuch ſuppreſſe foe heart conqueſt confeſſe hungarian moſt warrelike nation whilome woont purſue pray longer forced enemie yeeld vnto mercie wreſted confeſſion fromhim ſet libertie without offence ranſome except make ſweare never beare armes againſt wee get many advantage enemy borrowed qualitie porterlyraſcall vertue ſtronger armes ſturdier leg diſpoſition dead corporall qualitie tricke fortune make enemie ſtoope bleare eies sunneslight pranke skill knowledge cunning arte fencing may happen vnto baſe woorthleſſe man reputation woorth man conſiſteth heart therein conſiſts true honor conſtancie valour armes leg minde courage conſiſteth ſpirit courage horſe armes obſtinately faileth courage si ſucciderit de genu pugnat hee ſlip fall fight vpon knee danger imminent death whit danted aſſuredneſſe yeelding vp ghoſt holding enemie ſcornefull fierce looke vanquiſhed v fortune ſlaine conquered moſt valiant often moſt vnfortunate triumphant loſſes ground aegyptians ſculs without compariſon much harder perſians reaſon theſe go ever head covered coif turbants thoſe infancie ever ſhaven bareheaded king ageſilaus even decrepite age ever wont weare inſanos imbres coel • que ruinam bareheaded endure heavns ruine madraging ſhowre venetian hath long dwelt amongſt lately returned thence writteth kingdome pegu men woman part clad goe ever barefooted yea horſebacke alſo plato better health preſervation body doth earneſtly perſwade man ſhould ever give foot head cover nature hath allotted polonians chuſe king next may worthily eſteemed one greateſt prince age doth never weare glove wether ſoeuer winter ſummer bonnet broad warme houſe cannot endure goe vnbuttoned vntruſſed ſo huſbandmen neighbouring would feele themſelves fettred handbound going much man another condition principle ſimply conſider ſelfe without relation framing vpon owne modell though ſelfe continent yet ſincerely commend allow continencie capuchines theatines highly praiſe courſe life doe imagination inſinuate ſelfe place much ſelfe ſo much doe loue honour would gladly haue every man iudged apart drawne ſelfe conſequence others example weakeneſſe doth way alter opinion ſhould force vigor thoſe deſerve sunt qui nihil ſuadent quàm quod ſe imitari poſſe confidunt bee cic orat ad br ſuch adviſe nothing trust themſelves imitate crawling face earth ceaſe marke even cloud ſloth r • ot pride great calamity theſe implide evill rooted mide cannot ſcape ſelfe culpa eſt animus qui ſe non effugit vnquam hor l 1 epiſt 14▪ 15▪ minde greateſt fault muſt lie ſelfe never flie therefore muſt reduced brought ſelfe true ſolitarineſſe may enjoyed even frequencie peopled city king court commodiouſly enjoied apart ſithence wee vndertake live ſolitarie without companie let v cauſe contentment depend ſelves let v ſhake bondes tie v vnto others gaine victorie v good earneſt may live ſolitarie therein live eaſe stilphon eſcaped combuſtion citie wherein loſt wife child good demetrius polsorcetes ſeeing ſo great ruine countrie vnaffrighted countenance demaunded whether received loſſe anſwered thanks given god loſt nothing owne antiſthenes philoſopher ſaid verie pleaſantly charius quàm ipſe est ſibi fie man ſhould caſt aught himſelfe himſelfe belovd ſhould solitarineſſe mee ſeemeth hath apparance reaſon thoſe given moſt active flouriſhing age vnto world imitation thales lived long enough others live remainder life vnto ſelves let v bring home cogitation invention vnto ſelves vnto eaſe eaſie matter make ſafe retreit doth overmuch trouble v joyning enterpriſes vntoit since god give v leaſure diſpoſe diſlodging letvs prepare ſelves vntoit packe wee vp baggage let v betimes bid companie farewell shake theſe violent holdfaſts elſewhere engage v eſtrange v ſelves theſe ſo ſtrong bond muſt vntied man may eſtſoones love wed nothing himſelfe ſay let reſt owne yet ſo combined glued together may ſundred without fleaingvs therewithall pull away ſome piece owne greateſt thing world man know owne high time ſhakeoff ſocietie ſince bring nothing cannot lend let take heed borrowing force failevs retire ſhut vp ſelves ſuppreſſe confound himſelfe office ſo many amity companie let doe fall make v inutile irkſome importunate others let take heed importunate irkſome vnprofitable himſelfe let flatter court cheriſh himſelfe let governe himſelfe reſpecting reaſon fearing conſcience ſo may without ſhame ſtumble trip preſence rarum eſt enim vt ſatis ſe quiſ que vereatur rare matter every man ſufficiently ſhould ſtand awe reuerence himſelfe socrates ſaith yong men ought inſtructed men exerciſed well old men withdraw themſelves civill militarie negotiation living owne diſcretion without obligation certaine office ſome complexion proper theſe precept retreit others thoſe tender demiſſe apprehenſion ſqueamiſh affection delicate eaſilie ſubject imploy ſelfe naturall condition propenſe diſcourſe one better apply themſelves vnto counſell▪ active mind buſie ſpirits embrace every engage thing paſſionate themſelves offer preſent yeeld themſelves occaſions man muſt make vſe theſe accidentall commodity without v ſo long pleaſing v make principall foundation ſo reaſon nature permitit ſhould againſt lawes ſubject contentment power others moreover anticipate accident fortune man deprive himſelfe commodity hath poſſeſſion many done devotion ſome philoſophers diſcourſe ſerve themſelves lie vpon hard ground pull owne eye caſt rich sea ſeek paine ſmart ſome tormenting life happineſſe another otherſome placing themſelves loweſt ſtep thereby warrant themſelves fauoured running ſtiffe necke outſtretcht head like roaſted pigg alphonſus king spaine firſt eſtabliſhed order knight called order bend skarfe amongſt rule deviſed one none vpon paine forfait marke ſilver every time offending ſhould ever ride either mule mulet lately read guevara epiſtles whoſoever called golden epiſtles gave iudgement farre different mine courtier ſaith time counted great ſhame gentleman ſeene riding vpon mule whereas abyſſines contrary opinion accordingly advanced place honor dignitie prince called preſteriohn ſo doe affect ſigne pompe ſtate ride vpon largegreat mule xenophon reporteth aſſirians ever wont keepe horſes faſttied fetter gyves ever ſtable ſo wilde furious required ſo much time vnſhackle harniſh leaſt protracting ſo long time might ſhould chance vnawares vnreadie ſurpriſed enemy endomage never tooke vp quarter place except wel dyked intrenched cirus maketh ſo cunning horſemanſhip alwaies keepe horſes certaine ſtint would never ſuffer haue meate deſerved ſame ſweate ſome exerciſe scithians time warre chanced brought neceſſitie victual readieſt remedie let horſes blood quenched thirſt nouriſhed themſelves venit epoto sarmata paſtus people indie spaniardes came firſt amongſt eſteemed aſwell men horſes eyther god creature far beyond excelling nature nobilitie vanquiſhed comming ſue peace beg pardon handes brought preſents gold offrings ſacrifices firſt errour according opinion never continue immutable man even firſt infancie vnto latter age two ſucceeding may admit ſome conſtancie juſtice power inſeparable vaine implore latter yeares taken vp faſhion checke reproove men profeſſed catholike religion ſhined extraordinarie brightneſſe ſpirit ſaying fained doe honour held whatſoever ſaid apparance could inwardly chuſe fortune hope threat eternall life may beleeve thing could attempted youth ambition hazard difficultie followed latemoderne enterprize ſhould good part therein without great reaſon poore judgement church forbiddeth confuſed raſh indiſcreet vſe ſacred divine ſongs holie ſpirit hath indited vnto david god ought commixed action awfull reverence attention full honour reſpect word voice divine vſe exerciſe lung pleaſe eares conſcience tongue muſt proceed conſonant vnto reaſon prentiſe ſhopkeeping boy amiddeſt idle vaine frivolous conceit ſhould ſuffered entertaine himſelfe play therewith way paſtime tumultuarie handled ought fixed purpoſed ſetled action preface office ſurſum corda ſhould ever adioyned verie exterior part bodie ſhould ſuch countenance referred vnto men eye may witneſſe particular attention duteous reſpect ſtudie fitting men onely ſuch vowed themſelves vntoit god hath infinit mercie called thereto wicked vngodly ignorant thereby empaired hiſtorie fabulouſly reported hiſtorie dutifully reverenced awfully feared religiouſly adored pleaſantly conceited becauſe reduced ſame vulgar tongue men may vnderſtandit perſwade themſelves people ſhall better conceive digeſt ſame conſiſtethit word vnderſtand find written shall ſay approaching thus little vnto goe backe meere ignorance wholy relying others verily profitable wiſer verball vaine knowledge nurſe preſumption ſourſe temeritie moreover opinion vncontrouled libertie men wreſt diſſipate wyredraw word ſo religious important ſo many ſeverall idiomes hath much danger profit followingit iewes mahometans wellnigh nation wedded vnto reverence language wherein myſteries religion originally conceived change tranſlation hath without apparance reaſon directly forbidden know whether iudges enow baſque brittanie inſtability poſture whoſoever looketh narrowly himſelfe ſhall hardly ſee himſelfe twiſe one ſame ſtate somtimes give ſoule one viſage ſometimes another according vnto poſture ſide lay hir ſpeake turne ſelfe whoſoever ſhall heedefully ſurvay conſider ſelfe ſhall finde volubilitie diſcordance himſelfe yea judgement nothing ſay entirely ſimply ſoliditie ſelfe without confuſion diſorder blending mingling one word diſtinguo moſt vniverſall part logike although ever purpoſe ſpeake good good rather enterprete thoſe thing beare vnto good ſenſe yet ſtrangenes condition admitteth often vrged doe wel vice ſelfe wel judged intention therefore may couragious acte conclude man valiant ſo juſt occaſion ſerveth ſhall ever ſo vpon occaſions habitude vertue ſodaine humour would make man equally dangerous paſſages afterward better adviſed firſt wonder alſo poet often ſurpriſed rapt admiration owne labour forget trace paſt ſo happy career ſome terme fury madneſſe plato ſaith ſetled repoſed man doth vaine knocke poeſies gate ariſtotle likewiſe ſaith excellent minde freely exempted ſome entermixture folly hath reaſon call ſtarting extraordinarie conceit commendable ſoever exceedeth judgement diſcourſe folly forſomuch wiſedome orderly regular managing minde ſhe addreſſeth meaſure conducteth proportion take hir owne word forit plato diſputeth thus facultie propheſiyng divination far abovevs wee treate muſt beſides ſelves wiſdome muſt darkened ouer ſhadowed ſleepe ſickeneſſe drowzineſſe ſome celeſtiall fury raviſhed hir owne ſeat third chapter cuſtome ile cea ſome ſay philoſophate doubt ſwayvs hath hir ranke beyond theſe humane vaine conteſtations philip armed hand entred countrie peloponneſus ſome one told damidas lacedemonians like endure much ſought reobtaine loſt favour oh varlet thou art anſwered ſuffer feare death agis demanded man might live free anſwered deſpiſing contemning die theſe thouſand like propoſitions concurre purpoſe evidently inferre ſome thing beyond patient expecting death ſelfe ſuffered life witneſſe lacedemonian child taken antigonus ſold ſlave vrged maſter performe ſome abject ſervice thou ſhalt ſee ſaid thou haſt bought ſhame ſerve libertie ſo neere hand therewithall threw himſelfe headlong downe top houſe antipater ſharply threatning lacedemonians make yeeld certaine requeſt anſwered ſhouldeſt thou menace v worſe death rather die philip written vnto would hinder enterpriſes ſay wilt thou alſo hinder v dying reaſon ſome ſay wiſeman liveth long ought ſo long favourableſt gift nature hath bequeathedvs removeth meanes fromvs complaine condition ſhe hath leftvs key fieldes hath appointed one entrance vnto life many thouſand wayes well may want ground live vpon never ground die boiocatus anſwered romanes dooſt thou complaine againſt world doth father ſeemely may aſwell appeare ſet himſelfe forward manner voyage warres aſwell land ſea doe prince good ſervice court elſe ſonne hath neede part ought truly impart ſo forget himſelfe others ſuch may juſtly anſwere ſerve father commonly mouthes put clothes readie goe bed father overburthend yeares crazed ſickeneſſe reaſon weakeneſſe want health barred common ſocietie men doth wrong himſelfe injure idely vſe hoorde vp keepe cloſe great heape rich deale pelfe ſtate good enough wiſe deſire put clothes goe bed ſay ſpirt good warme night gowne pompe traſh whereof hee hath longer vſe neede hee ought willingly diſtribute beſtow amongſt thoſe naturall decree ought belong reaſon ſhould vſe bequeath fruition ſince nature doth alſo deprive otherwiſe without doubt envy malice ſtirring worthieſt action ever emperour charles fifth performed imitation ſome ancient quality diſcretion know reaſon commanded v ſtrip ſhift ſelves cloathes trouble heavie v high time goe bed legges faile v reſigned meanes greatneſſe kingdome sonne time found former vndanted reſolution decay force conduct aſlaires droope himſelfe together glory thereby acquired solue ſeneſcentem mature ſe •• equum nemor 1 • ep 1 8 peccet ad extremum ridendus ilium ducat wiſe horſe growne▪ old time caſt leaſt laſt fall lame ſoulter breed skoffe fault man able know himſelfe betimes feele impuiſſance extreame alteration age doth naturally bring body minde mine opinion equall minde one halfe hath loſt reputation moſt part greateſt men world day ſeene fam • liarly knowen ſome men great authority man might eaſily deſcerne ſtrangely fallen ancient ſufficiency know reputation thereby attained▪ vnto beſt yeares could willingly honor ſake wiſ • home owne buſineſſe diſcharged negotiation commonwealth employment war longer fit ſometimes familiar gentleman houſe old man widdower yet luſty age man many daughter • ariageable ſonne growne man ſtate readie appeare world thing drew▪ cauſe great charge many viſitations wherein tooke little pleaſure onely continuall care hee ſave reaſon age hee betaken himſelfe manner life farre different chanced one day tell ſomewhat boldly cuſtome would better beſeeme give v place reſigne chiefe houſe ſon mannorhouſe conveniently well furniſhed quietly retire himſelfe ſome farme man might trouble diſturbe reſt ſince could otherwiſe avoide importunitie ſeeing condition child afterward followed counſell found great eaſe ſaid thing given ſuch way obligation man may recall againe readie play ſuch part would give vnto full poſſeſſion houſe enjoying good ſuch libertie limited condition beleeve hero dotus reporteth certaine province libia often followeth great error miſtaking ſaith men doe indifferently vſe common frequent woman childe ſoone able goe comming ſolemne meeting great vnto poeſie would eſteeme greater honour father ʋirgils aeneidos goodlieſt boy rome would rather endure loſſe one periſhing according ariſtotle workemen poet principally moſt amorous production conceited labour eaſie believed epaminondas vanted leave ſome daughter behind vnto poſterity ſhould one day highly honour father two famous victory gained lacedemonians would ever given free conſent hir feare menace wherewith ſhe threatneth miſbeleevers follow hir promiſes conſiderations ought applied employed beleefe subſidiaries humane bondes another country teſtimonies equall promiſes alike menace mighe ſemblably imprint cleane contrary religion v weare chriſtians ſame title either perigordins german plato ſaith • ew ſo confirmed atheiſme ſome great danger bring vnto knowledge god divine power parte doth touch concernea good chriſtian mortall worldly religion received humane convoy faith like cowardice heart doth plant weakneſſe eſtabliſh v goodly faith belief beleeveth onely becauſe wanteth courage beleeve ſame vicious paſſion inconſtancie aſtoniſhment poſſibly ground regular production mindes ſoules eſtabliſh ſaith reaſon judgement whatſoever reported hell aftercomming paine fiction occaſions make triall offering ſelfe time age ſickenes doth ſommon death errour ſame horrour future condition doth repleniſh kinde beleefe becauſe ſuch impreſſions make men heart fearefull hee lawes inhibiteth inſtruction ſuch threat perſwaſion evill may come vnto man god except greater good medicinable effect whenſoever falleth intoit report bion infected athieſmes theodorus along time made mockerie religious men death ſeize vpon yeelded vnto extreameſt ſuperſtions god would either remooved come againe according bions buſineſſe plato theſe example conclude wee brought beleeve god either reaſon compulſion atheiſme propoſition vnnaturall monſtrous harde vneaſie eſtabliſhed man minde inſolent vnruly ſoever hee may many beene ſeene conceived either vanitie fierceneſſe ſtrange ſeldknowne opinion would become reformer world affecting profeſſion onely countenaunce though ſufficiently fooliſh yet powerfull enough ground ſettle conſciences yet ſuch leave liſtvp joyned hand v greateſt part beaſts ſeverall motion limb naturally without teaching reape ſerviceable vſe thoſe trained vp fight naked ſeene head long caſt themſelves ſame hazard danger doe ſome beaſts excell v advantage exceede many others induſtrie enable skill fortifie wit ſhelter cover body artificiall meanes kind naturall inſtinct teaching prove elephant doth whet ſharpen histeeth vſeth warre hath ſome ancienteſt moſt certaine ſuch drawen flight bird nothing equall vnto ſo admirable rule fluttering order ſhaking wing conjecture conſequences thing enſue muſt neceſſarily directed ſo noble operation ſome excellent ſupernaturall meane wreſting letter attribute ſo wondrous effect naturall decree without knowledge conſent diſcourſe cauſeth produceth moſt falſe opinion proove torpedo crampfiſh hath property benumme aſtoniſh onely limbes thoſe touch alſo long pole fiſhing line touch part thereof ſhee doth tranſmit convey kinde heavie numming hand thoſe ſtirre handle ſame moreover averred matter caſt vpon aſtoniſhment ſenſibly felt gaine vpward vntill come handes even water aſtoniſheth feelingſence wonderfull power yet altogether vnprofitable crampfiſh ſhe knowes make vſe catch prey ſhe purſueth ſhe ſeene hide hirſelfe vnder mudde fiſhes ſwimming hir ſtrucken benummed hir exceeding coldneſſe may fall hir clawes crane swallowes wandering birdes changing abode according ſeaſons yeare iacebuntluer li 4 982 ſomnis ſudare tamen ſpiraréque ſaepe et quaſi de palma ſummas contendere vires ſhall ſee warlike horſes ſleep lims lie yet ſweat ſnorting keep ſtretch vtmoſt ſtrength goale length hare greyhound imagineth dreame ſleepeth ſee bay queſt yelp ſnort ſtretch taile ſhake leg perfectly repreſent motion courſe ſame hare without bone without haire ʋenantúmque cane molli ſepae quieteibid 986 iactant crus tamen ſubitè vocèſque repente mittunt crebras redducunt naribus aura vt veſtigia ſi teneant inventa ferarum expergefactique ſequuntur inania ſepae cervorum ſimulacra fugae quaſi dedita cernant donee diſcuſſis redeant erroribus ad ſe oft time hunter dog eaſie reſt stir leg ſuddainly open queſt ſend noſtrels thickethicke ſnuffing ſent traile game fullbent wakened ſo ennius ſaidennius nimium boni est cui nihil est mali hath much good ill hath withſtood for▪ ſame tickling pricking man doth feel ſome pleaſures ſeemes beyond ſimple health indolencie active moving tempore verum eſt502 et ſi non potuit ratio diſſolvere cauſam cur ea qu • fuerint iuxtim quadrata procul ſint ʋiſa rotunda tamen praeſtat rationis egent • reddere mendosè cauſas vtriúſque figurae quàm manibus manifeſta ſuis emittere quoquam et violare fidem primam convellere tota fundamenta quibus nixatur vita ſalúſque non modò enim ratio ruat omnis vita quoque ipſa concidat extemplo niſi creder • greateſt captaine world nought ceremonie ceremonie doth tranſport▪ v wee leave ſubſtance thing wee holdfaſt bough leave trunke body taught lady bluſh onely hearing named nothing feare doe wee dare call member proper name feare employ kinde diſſoluteneſſe ceremonie forbids v word expreſſe lawfull naturall thing believe reaſon willeth v doe bad vnlawfull thing man giveth credite vnto heare find ſelfe entangled lawes ceremonie neither allowes man ſpeake ill good himſelfe therefore wee leave time thoſe fortune whether wee ſhall name good bad hath made paſſe life ſome eminent conſpicuous degree may publike action witneſſe thoſe ſhe never emploied baſe thing man ſhall ever ſpeake except themſelves doe excuſable dare ſpeake themſelves ſuch intereſt acquaintance example lucilius ille velut artificiall whereof ſpeake ſalutations reverence conge ſome doe often purchaſe honor wrongfully humble lowly courteous man may humble glory prodigall cappings namely summer never receive quality men countenaunces let v forget ſterne looke constantius emperour publike held ever head boltvpright without turning bending ſame ſide ſo much looke ſaluted ſideling holding body ſo fixt vnmooveable let coche ſhake never ſo much kept ſtill vpright durſt never ſpit wipe noſe dry face people wot whether thoſe geſtures noted firſt condition whether truth ſecret propenſion fault may well cannot anſwer motion body concerning thoſe ſoule heere ingeniouſly confeſſe thinke two part glory ſay man eſteeme himſelfe overmuch ſufficiently eſteeme others one firſt thinkes theſe conſiderations ought ſomewhat accompted feele ſelfe ſurcharged one errour minde bad much importunate vtterly diſlike endevour correct cannot diſplace becauſe abate juſt value thoſe thing poſſeſſe enhance worth thing much ſtrange abſent mine owne humour extends ſelfe farre doth prerogative authority wherewith husband looke vpon owne wife vicious diſdame many father vpon child doe betweene two like workes would ever weigh againſt mine ſo much jealouſie preferment amendment troubleth judgement hindereth pleaſing ſelfe maſtery hirſelfe begets contempt man poſſeſſeth oweth policy far cuſtomes tongue flatter perceive latine tongue favour hir dignity deceive beyond belongs vnto hir child vulgar ſort neighbour oeconomie houſe horſe though equall value worth mine much mine owne beſides becauſe moſt ignorant mine owne matter admire aſſurance wonder promiſe every man hath himſelfe whereas almoſt nothing wot know dare warrant ſelfe able doe faculty propoſition eſtate inſtructed effect doubtfull mine owne ſtrength vncertaine anothers force whence followeth commendably chance vpon one piece worke rather impute fortune aſcribe mine induſtry foraſmuch deſſeigne hazard feare likewiſe generall opinion antiquity hath man groſe thoſe moſt willingly embrace whereon take moſt hold ſuch moſt vilifie contemne annihilate v thinkes philoſophy hath never better cardes shew ſhe checketh preſumption croſſeth vanity good ſooth ſhe acknowledgeth hir irreſolution hir weakeneſſe hir ignorance ſeemeth good conceit ſelfeweening opinion man hath himſelfe nurcemother falſeſt opinion publike particular thoſe cockehorſe pearch part paiment get ſtart fellowes force violence doe much never weeſee merchant countreyiuſtices artificer march cheeke joll nobilitie valour military diſcipline performe honourable combates publike private batter defend townes city preſent warres prince ſmoothereth commendation amid throng let ſhine others humanitie truth loyaltie temperance iuſtice markes adaies rare vnknowen exiled people wherewith may effect pleaſeth quality allure ſo much profitableſt nihil est tam populare quam bonitas nothing ſo popular goodneſſe proportion beene rare great man certaine age paſt pigmey popular man common ſtronger quality concurre withall ſee man temperate revenge milde revenging offence religious keeping word neither double tractable applying faith others every occaſion would rather let affaire goe wrake breake word availe touching newfound vertue faining diſſimulation ſo much credit hate death vice finde none ſo much witneſſeth demiſſeneſſe baſeneſſe heart coward ſervile humour man diſguiſe hide himſelfe vnder maske dare ſhew himſelfe thereby men addreſſe themſelves trecherie trained vtter falſe word make conſcience breake generous minde ought belie thought make ſhew moſt part good leaſt humane ariſtotle thinkes office magnanimitie hate love openly iudge ſpeake libertie never though priſe truth goe make eſteeme either approbation ot reprobation others apollonius ſaid ſeruants lie freeman ſpeake truth cheefe fundamentall part vertue shee muſt loved owne ſake ſpeaketh truth becauſe hee bound doe ſo hee ſerveth feares tell lie little importeth another man ſufficiently true mind owne complexion deteſteth falſhood hateth think feele inward baſhfulneſſe ſtinging remorce time ſcape ſometimes doth vnpremeditated occaſions ſurpriſe man muſt alwaies ſay knowes follie man ſpeakes prince done boaſt ſhirt privie ſecret true cogitation would burne ſaying ancient metellus macedonicus cannot diſſemble cannot raigne ſerves warne thoſe deale ſay vntruth diſſimulation quo quis verſutior callidior eſt hoc inviſior ſuſpectior detract à opinione probitatis cic lib 1 finerheaded ſubtlebrained man hated ſuſpected opinion honeſtly taken great ſimplicity man ſuffer himſelfe miſled hee might ever confirme eſtabliſh goeth otherwiſe man may come ſuch bargaine man life concludeth one peace treatie commoditie profit enviteth firſt diſloyaltie daily ſome offer themſelves trecheries infinite prejudice mee rather importunate indiſcreet flatterer diſſembler allow man may entermingle ſome point fierceneſſe wilfulneſſe keepe himſelfe ſo entire open without conſideration others mee commoditie reaped philoſophie ſpake freely ſincerely men memory inſtrument great ſervice without judgement hardly diſcharge duty whereof great want man propoſe vnto muſt doe peecemeales anſwer diſcourſe hath many head lieth power cannot receive charge except writing table muſt remember diſcourſe conſequence length driven vile miſerable neceſſitie learne every word muſt ſpeake rote otherwiſe vnceſſantly altering matter make difficult bee confirmed author memory diſtruſt troubleth ſerveth better chance muſt careleſly ſollicite vrge ſhe aſtoniſhed beginne waver ſound entangled intricate touching conduct wiſedome hath ſmall ſhare therein eaſily directed world publike order oh happie people doth commanded better command without vexing themſelves cauſes ſuffer themſelves gently rowled according heaven rowling obedience never pure quiet talketh pleadeth contendeth ſome returne ſelfe onely matter make ſome accompt ſelfe wherein never man thinke himſelfe defective commendation vulgar common popular ever thought wanted wit propoſition itſelfe would imply contradiction infirmity never ſeene ſtrong faſtholding yet pierced diſſipated firſt beame pacients ſight doth sunnes ray ſcatter ſi quidquam eſt cic lib • decorum nihil eſt profectò magi quam aequabilitas vniverſae vitae tum ſingularum actionum quam conſervare non poſſis ſi aliorum naturam imitans omittas tuam clearely thing bee decent man▪ nothing even carriage equabilitie whole life every action therein cannot vphold following nature others let paſſe owne behold far forth finde ſelfe guilty firſt part ſaid vice preſumption concerning ſecond conſiſteth eſteeming ſufficiently others wot whether ſo well excuſe ſelfe whatſoeuer coſt mee intend ſpeake may continuall commerce ancient humour idea thoſe rich mindes former age doth bring liking diſtaſte others ſelfe truth live age produceth thing meane indifferent know nothing worthy great admiration alſo know many men ſo familiarly ſhould able judge thoſe quality condition doth ordinarily make converſant moſt part ſuch little care manuring ſoule nothing propoſed chiefe felicitie honour abſolute perfection valour whatſoever ſee beauteous worthy man willingly commend regard yea often endeare ſelfe thinke allow ſelfe lie ſo farre forth cannot invent falſe ſubject willingly witneſſe friend finde praiſeworthy inch valour willingly make inch halfe lend quality cannot openly defend imperfection may yea bee mine enemy ſhall ſincerely give due witneſſing worth honour affection may change judgement never confound quarrell circumſtances impertinent belong vnto ſo jealous liberty judgement paſſion ſo ever hardly quit wrong ſelfe lying lie commendable generous cuſtome perſian nation much noted ſpake honourably iustly mortall enemy thoſe deadly fude warre ſo farre foorth merit vertue deſerved know diver men ſundry noble worthy part ſome wit ſome courage ſome dexteritie ſome conſcience ſome readineſſe ſpeech ſome one science ſome another great man generall hath ſo many excellent part together one ſuch degree excellencie hee may thereby bee admired compared thoſe former age honour fortune hath permitted ſee one greateſt ever knew living meane naturall part minde beſt borne stephanus de la boitie verily compleat minde ſet good face ſhewed faire countenance vpon matter minde old ſtampe fortune therewith beene pleaſed would doubt brought forth wondrous effect skill ſtudy added much rich naturall gift know come paſſe ſurely doth ſo much vanitie weakeneſſe vnderſtanding found thoſe profeſſe moſt ſufficiencie entermeddle learned vacation charge depend bookes ſort people whether becauſe required expected hand common fault cannot excuſed ſelfeopinion knowledge emboldeneth produce diſcover themſelves overforward whereby looſe betray themſelves artificer doeth manifeſt ſottiſhneſſe rich piece worke hath hand fooliſhly againſt rule trade ſeeke apply entermeddle vile baſe one men offended fault overſight ſtatue gold one clay theſe doe much ſet foorth thing themſelves place would bee good employ without diſcretion honouring memory coſt charge vnderſtanding honour cicero galen ʋlpian saint ierome make themſelves ridiculous • iſhed revolved ••• •• 4 l 2 thing ſo different elder report simonides becauſe imagination concerning queſtion hyeron king made vnto better anſwer diverſe date allowed thinke preſented ſundry ſubtill ſharpe conſiderations vnto doubting might likelieſt altogether diſpaired truth whoſoever ſearcheth circumſtances embraceth conſequences therof hindereth election meane engine doth equally conduct ſufficeth execution great little weight commonly ſeene beſt husband thriſtieſt thoſe cannot tell ſo theſe cunning arethmeticians doe ſeldome thrive know notable pratler excellent blazoner ſorts husbandry thrift hath moſt pitteouſly let ten thouſand pound ſterline yeare paſſe know another ſaith conſulteth better man counſell cannot properer man ſee vnto ſufficiency notwithſtanding commeth execution owne ſervants finde farre otherwiſe ſay without mentioning accounting ill lucke one twentieth chapter idleneſſe nothing emperour vespaſian lying ſicke diſeaſe whereof died omitted endevour vnderſtand ſtate empire lying bed vnce •• antly diſpatched many affaire great conſequence phiſitians chiding thing hurtfull health anſwered emperour ſhould die ſtanding vpright loe heere notable ſince cannot bee joyned firſt part take ſhare ſecond maſſacre blood murthers victory commonly effected baſer kinde people officer waite vpon baggage cariage reaſon ſee ſo many vnheardof cruelty vrſiovid triſt li 3 • l 5 35 —et quaecumque minor nobilitate fera eſt wolfe filthie beare dying man oppreſſe ſome ſuch beaſt nobilitie leſſe craven curres home kennel tugge bite skinnes thoſe wilde beare enemie make end keepe bay make die moreouer deſire revenge thereby alayed better contented aymeth nothing ſo much give ſhew motion feeling reuenge onely ſelfe thats thereaſon reaſon doe chalenge adverſary though lived aud wronged whereas quake feare ſo long ſee foote ſo doth moderne practize purſue death well hath wronged v offended alſo kinde daſtardlineſſe hath brought faſhion onr ſingle company ſoever doth naturally bring ſome comfort eaſe danger ancient time wont employ third perſons ſticklers ſee trechery diſorder vſed beare witnes combates ſucceſſe faſhion come vp let man engaged —coniugium pudor eſt non licuiſſe mori ardent victrices flammae pectora praebent —imponúnt que ſuis peruſt viris deathbed laſt flame applide looſe haires many kind wife ſtand ſide ſtrive death alive may next hir wedlocke may ſhamd vext orecome burnd flame give way body burnt burnt husband lay late writer affirmeth himſelfe hath ſeene cuſtome highly reputed new diſcovered eaſt indiaes wife buried husband alſo ſuch ſlaves hee hath enjoyed done manner husband deceaſed widdow may ſhe fewe doe requeſt two three moneths ſpace diſpoſe hir buſines day come adorned ſumptuous bride ſhe mounteth horſebacke cheerful countenance tell eth every body ſhe going lie hir bride groome holding left hand lookingglaſſe arrow right thus rid vp downe great pompe magnificence accompanied friendes kinſmen much concourſe people feaſt jolitie ſhe brought vnto publike place purpoſely appointed ſuch ſpectacles large open place middeſt whereof pit grave full wood neere vnto vpraiſed ſcaffold foure five ſteppes aſcend vpon ſhe brought ſerved ſtately ſumptuous banket ended ſhe beginneth dance ſing ſhe think good commandeth fire kindled done ſhe commeth downe againe taking neareſt hir husband kindred hand goe together nex river ſhee ſtrippes hir ſelfe naked diſtributeth hir jewel clothes among hir friend plungeth herſelfe water ſhe meant waſh away hir ſins comming ſhe enwrappeth herſelfe yellow piece linnen cloth length fourteene yard giving hir hand againe vnto hir husband kinſman returne vnto mount ſhe ſpeakes vnto people ſhe ſhe recommendeth hir child betweene pitte mount commonly manured called ſaid thus away bad man angrie would whipt plato likewiſe vexed angrie one ſlaves commaunded speuſippus puniſh excuſing himſelfe angrie would lay hand vpon charillus lacedemonian ilelot cuntrey hinde behaved himſelfe inſolently audaciouſly towards god ſaid angrie would preſently make thee die paſſion pleaſeth flattereth ſelfe many time moved falſe ſuggeſtion iuſtant preſented lawfull burning redoubled ſlie deviſe paſſion inſtantly preſented mind made three guiltie forſomuch one found innocent cauſed three diſpat • h • firſt souldier becauſe aliedie condemned ſecond ſtrag • ed abroade reaſon cauſe fellowes death hangman fulfilled generalles commaundement thoſe deale froward skittiſh woman doubt ſeen rage wil fal moſt angrie cha • ing man ſilent patient diſdaine foſter anger wrath celius orator nature exceeding fretfull cholerike one ſupper man milde gentle converſation becauſe would moue ſeemed approve ever ſaid yeelde every thing vnable endure peeviſhnes ſhould ſo paſſe without ſome nouriſhment burſt rage ſaid vnto love god deny ſomething may two woman never angrie end man ſhould againe angrie therein imitating lawes love phocion man troubled diſcourſe brawling skolding moſt injurious manner nothing elſe holde peace given leaſure hee would vent choller done without taking notice began diſcourſe againe hee left reply ſo ſharpe ſuch ſilent contempt moſt chollerike teaſtie man france ever imperfection excuſable military man muſt needes granted profeſſion ſome men cannot well avoyde ever ſay hee patienteſt man knowe bridle choller mooveth trannſporteth ſuch furie violence —magno veluti cùm flamma ſonore virg ae • lib 462 ʋirgea ſuggeritur coſt vndantis aheni exultántque aeſtu latex furit • u aquaï fumidus atque al • è ſpumis exuberat amnis nec iam ſe capit vnda volat vapor ater ad aura fago • flame hurring ſounds vnder ribbes boyling cauldron lie water ſwelles heat beyond bound whence ſteeming ſtreames raging foming riſe water outrunns ſelfe blacke vapor flye sky hee muſt cruelly enforce himſelfe moderate ſame part knowe noe paſſion able • mother ſuch temper abide ſuch reſolution would ſet wiſedome ſo high rate reſpect ſo much hee doth much coſts doe worſe another boaſted preſence behauiours order mildeneſſe truth ſingular tolde indeede much namely men ſo eminent qualitie himſelfe whome eye fixed alwayes ſhew himſelfe good temper chiefeſt point conſiſted providing inwardly himſelfe mine opinion noe diſcreete parte inwardly fret maintaine marke formall outward apparance feared hee choller incorporated concealing ſmothering ſame diogenes ſaide demoſthenes fearing ſeene taverne withdrew himſelfe ſame thou recoyleſt backe thou goeſt woulde rather perſwade man though ſomewhat ſeaſon give boy whirret ea • e diſſemble wiſe ſterne terrorbreeding lowes horne anger proof striving againſt tree trunke winde ſtrokes preface made fight ſca • tered ſand provokes chance angry earneſt • ſt manner may yet briefly ſecretly poſſible looſe ſelfe haſtineſſe violence trouble let ſpend maner injurious wordes random without heede never reſpect place point pertinently may doe moſt hurt commonly employ nothing tongue boyes ſcape better cheape great matter ſmall trifle slight occaſions ſurpriſe michiefe falne pit matter thruſts never ceaſe till come bottome fall preſſeth haſteneth mooveth furthereth ſelfe great occaſions pleaſed ſo juſt every body expects reaſonable anger inſue glorify ſelfe deceive expectation againſt theſe bandy prepare ſelfe make ſummon vp wit threaten carry farre would follow eaſily keepe ſelfe falling ſtay ſtronge enough reject impulſion paſſion violent cauſe ſoever hath ſeize vpon preoccupate vaine cauſe ſoever hath doth cleane tranſport condition thus thoſe may conteſt perceve firſt angry right wrong let holdon courſe like ever ſhall come lot rage engendred concurrencie choler eaſily produced one another borne one inſtant let v allow every man courſe ſo ſhall ever peace oh profitable preſcription gentleman thuſcanie qualis gemma micat flavum quae dividit aurumvirg ae •• 10 134 aut collo decus aut capiti vel quale per artem incluſum buxo aut ericia terebintho lucet ebur precious ſtone cleare rayes doth ſpread set pure golde adorning necke head faire vry ſhines boxe enclosd workemanly mountaine gumme diſposd endowed ſo alluringlyexceſſive ſingular beautie chaſteſt eye could poſſibly rich gift nature ſo prodigally conferred vpon muſt beare blame others fault gaſhes skars wittingly mangled voluntarily cutthat perfect proportion abſolute feature nature ſo curiouſly obſerved vnmatched face whereof ſpeake opinion ſuch rage enemy rule rather admire honour ſuch action intent commendable purpoſe conſciencious ſeeming ſomewhat wanting wiſedome deformitie vglineſſe afterward inſtrument induce others fall ſinne contempt vice hatred fault envy glory ſo rare commendation ſlander interpreting humour bee franticke ambition forme whence vice ſo pleaſe may wreſt occaſion ſome maner exerciſe ſelfe beene juſt therewithall glorious ſo rare gift god made ſubject exemplar vertue orderly methode thoſe ſequeſter themſelves publike office infinite number thornie ſo manyfaced rule civill life binde man exact honeſty exquiſite integritie mine opinion reape goodly commoditie peculiar ſharpeneſſe ſoever enjoyne themſelves kinde death avoide paine welldoing trouble wellliving may another priſe priſe vneaſines think never difficulty thing amid wave worldly multitude beyond keeping himſelfe vpright vntainted anſwering loyally truely diſcharging member ſeverall part charge happily eaſie one honeſt ſort neglect paſſe ſexe duely wholly maintaine himſelfe wife companie man may incuriouſly fall povertie plenteouſneſſe juſtly diſpenſed cuſtome according reaſon doth leade ſharpneſſe abſtinence hath moderation vertue much toyleſome ſufferance chaſte well living yong scipio hath thouſand ſeverall faſhions diogenes one doth ſo much exceede ordinary life innocencie vnſpottedneſſe thoſe moſt exquiſite accompliſhed exceede profite outgoe force foure thirtieth chapter obſervations concerning meanes warre maner iulius caeſar reported diver chiefe general warre machiavell much accompted late marſhall strozzi made eſpeciall choiſe love caeſar without doubt thinke choſe beſt truely ought breviarie true souldiers beeing abſolute perfect chiefe patterne military profeſſion god hee knowes grace decorum hee hath embelliſhed rich ſubject ſo pure kinde ſpeech ſo pleaſing ſo abſolutely perfect taſte writing world ſubject may bee compared heere regiſter certaine particular rare part concerning maner warre yet remaine memory armie beeing ſome afrighted vpon report ranne great force king iuba brought againſt inſtead abating opinion ſoldiers conceived diminiſh meanes force enemie cauſed aſſembled altogether thereby aſſure incourage tooke cleane contrary courſe like caſes accuſtomed bad troble themſelves finde number force enemy brought againſt himſelfe indeede conceived opinion weakeneſſe enured souldiers ſimply obey without controling gaineſaying ſpeaking captaines deſſeignes never communicated vnto vpon laſt point execution pleaſed chance inkling ſo deceive preſently change opinion prefixt place quarterin night hee hath often beene ſeene march lengthen journey namely weather foule rained swizzers beginning warres gaule ſent toward give free paſſage roman country reſolved force empeach notwithſtanding ſhew good lookes tooke certaine dayes reſpit give anſwere time might leaſure aſſemble armie together theſe poore people knew well could husband time often repeated skill embrace occaſisons nicke chiefeſt parte abſolute captaine truely diligence vſed exploit incredible like never heard conſciencious vnder colour ſome treatie parlie accord take advantage enemy hee little ſcrupulous required vertue souldiers valour except mutinie diſobedience puniſhed grealy vice victory hee often gave reines licentiouſneſſe diſpenſing rule military diſcipline ſaying moreover ſouldiers ſo well inſtructed though theit gayeſt clothes pranked vp musked perfumed would notwithſtanding runne furiouſly combate truth hee loved ſee richly armed caeſar paſt rheine generall fellow heere ſinne ſtaines make fellowesal cuſtome overlowelie dignitie emperor chiere generall armie brought vp faſhion againe call ouly souldiers curteſie caeſar notwithſtanding intermixe great ſeverity ſuppreſſe keep humble ninth legion mutined neere vnto placentia hee preſently caſſiered ſame great ignominie vnto notwithſtanding pompey yet foote ſtrong would receive favour humble petition entreatie hee appeaſe authoritie audacitie mildeneſſe affabilitie hee ſpeaketh paſſage river rheine towardes germanie hee ſaith deeming vnworthy honour romane people army ſhould paſſe ſhippes cauſed bridge built ſo might paſſe driefoote hee erected admirable bridge whereof ſo particularly deſcribeth frame hee never willingly dilates himſelfe deſcribing exploites hee endeuoreth repreſent vnto v ſubtilitie invention ſuch kindes manuall workes alſo noted booke hee much accompteth exhortation made sculdiers fight would ſhew beene either ſurpriſed vrged ever alledgeth hee ſo much leaſure make oration souldiers armie great battell againſt thoſe tournay caeſar ſaith diſpoſed reſt ranne ſodainely whither fortune carried exhort men meeting tenth legion hee leaſure ſay thing elſe vnto ſhould remember former wonted vertue ſhould nothing danted ſhould stoutly reſiſt encounter adverſaries foraſmuch enemie come within arrowſhoote vnto gave ſignall battell collected knew phraſes word firſt time publike charge hee iſſued rome hee came eight dayes river rhone ever one two secretary continually writ hee endited one behinde carried ſword ſurely one nothing runne vp downe could hardly attaine promptitude wherewith ever victorious left gaule following pompey brunduſium eighteene dayes ſabdued italie returned brunduſium rome thence went even hart spaine paſt many extreame difficulty warres betweene afranius petreius long ſiege marſeille whence returned macedon overthrew romane armie pharſalia thence purſuing pompey hee paſſed aegipt ſubdued aegipt vnto nowadayes wee ſhould doe would never allow meanes never ſo certaine get victory warres againſt ariovistus whileſt parly ſome tumult inſurrection happened betweene two army beganne fault negligence ſome arioviſtus horſmen hurlieburlie caeſar found himſelfe great advantage en • emies notwithſtanding would embrace feare might taxed ſuſpected proceeded falſly conſented trechery time ceremonious countenance looketh ſo much backeward foreward rather purchaſe payment mine infancie honeſt moſt faire ladie yet liveth widdowe prince ſomewhat wot hir attire lawes widowehood would well permit ſuch blamed hir • ſaid ſhee becauſe intend new acquaintance mind marry againe becauſe altogether diſſent cuſtome heere made choiſe three woman alſo employed vtmoſt endevor goodnes affection husbandes deathes yet example ſomewhat different ſo vrging hardly drawe life conſequence plinie yonger dwelling neere vnto houſe italie neighbour wonderfully tormented certaine vlcers much troubled ſecret part wife perceiving droope languiſh away entreated ſhe might leaſurely ſearch neerely view qualitie diſeaſe ſhe would freely tell hee hope obtained curiouſly conſidered ſame ſhee found impoſſible ever cured might expect lead long dolorous languiſhing life therefore ſafetie ſoveraigne remedie perſwaded kill himſelfe finding ſomewhat nice backeward effect ſo rude enterpriſe thinke deare friend quoth ſhee ſorrowes griefes ſee thee feele touch neere may ſelfe rid applie ſame remedie ſelfe preſcribe thee accompanie thee thy cure done thy ſickeneſſe remoove feare aſſure ſelfe ſhall pleaſure paſſage ſhall deliver v torment happily goe together ſaid cheared vp husband courage ſhe determined ſhould headlong throw themſelves ſea window houſe looked ſame maintaine loyall vehement never ſevered affection end wherewith ſhee life embraced ſhee would alſo die armes fearing might faile fall feare apprehenſion holdfaſt might looſed ſhee cauſed herſelfe faſt bound vnto middle thus vestigia fecitvirg georg il 2 473 iuſtice departing earth take leave laſt paſſage make two noble rich example vertue rarely lodged arria wife vnto cecinna paetus man beene conſul mother another arria wife thraſea paetus whoſe vertue ſo highly renowmed time nero meane ſonneinlawe grandmother fannia reſemblance theſe men woman name fortune hath made diverſe miſtake firſt arria husband cecinna paetus beene taken priſoner souldiers claudius emperour overthrow scribonianus whoſe faction hee followed entreated thoſe led priſoner rome▪ take ſhip ſervice husband ſhee ſhould leſſe charge incommoditie number perſons muſt neceſſarily ſhe alone might ſupply ſteade chamber kitchin office vtterly refuſed ſo hoiſed ſailes ſhee leaping fiſhers boate ſhe immediately hired followed aloofe ſhoare sclavonia come rome one day emperours preſence iunia widdow scribonianus reaſon neereneſſe ſocietie fortune familiarly accoſted ſhe rudely theſe wordes thruſt away quoth ſhee ſhall ſpeake thee ſhall liſten thou ſaieſt thou whoſe lappe scribonianus thy husband ſlaine thou yet liveſt thou breatheſt theſe word diver ſignes made kinsfolkes friendes perceive ſhee purpoſed make herſelfe away impatient abide husband fortune thraſea ſonne law taking hold ſpeeches beſeeching ſhe wold ſo vnheedily ſpoile ſelfe thus beſpake cecinnaes fortune like would wife daughter doe ſo elſe make queſtion anſwered ſhe yes mary would ſhe lived ſo long ſo goodagreeing ſort thee done husband theſe ſuchlike anſweres encreaſed care made heedfully watch neerely looke vnto one day ſhe vttered theſe wordes keeper may looke long enough mee well may make mee die worſe ſhall never able keepe dying therewith furiouſly flinging ſelfe chaire wherein ſhee fate ſtrength ſhee ſhe fiercely ranne head againſt next wall blowe ſore hurt ſelfe falling dead ſwowne much adoe brought ſelfe againe tell quoth ſhe kept eaſie death would chooſe another hard difficult ſoever end ſo admirable vertue husband paetus wanting courage doe himſelfe death vnto emperor crueltie reſerved one day firſt employed diſcourſes exhortation befitting counſell ſhe gave make himſelfe away ſhee tooke dagger husband wore holding outright hand period exhortation doe thus paetus ſaid ſhee inſtant ſtabbing herſelfe mortally heart preſently pulling dagger againe ſhee reached ſame vnto husband ſo yeelded vp ghoſt vttering noble generous immortall ſpeech▪ paete non dolet ſhee leaſure pronounce theſe three wordes ſubſtance materiall worthy ſelfe holde paetus hath done hurt caſta ſuo gladium cùm traderet arria paetoma • li 1 epig 14 1 quem de viſceribus traxerat ipſa ſuis si qua fides vulnus quod feci non dolet inquit sed quod tu facies id mihi paete dolet chaſt arria ſhe gave paetus ſharpe ſword bowells ſhe drawne forth bleeding new wound priſe regard whit leſſe hee cannot looſe himſelfe handſomelie excuſable wee cannot doe every thing bee euery place done thus thus muſt wee often vnto laſt anker ſole refuge reſigne protection common good rate honeſtie ſacred senate ſelfe meanes deliuered thraldome durſt definitively decide ſo haughtie action rend two ſo vrgent different ſemblances siracuſans opportunelie inſtant ſent corinthian require protection gouernour able reeſtabliſh towne former maieſtie deliuer sicilie number pettie tyrant greeuouſhe oppreſſed ſame appointed timoleon new caucat declaration according hee ſhould well ill demeane himſelfe charge ſentence ſhould encline either grace redeemer country diſgrace murtherer brother fantaſticall concluſion hath ſome excuſe vpon danger example importance act ſo different well diſcharge iudgement embarke ſome elſe conſiderations proceeding timoleon renowned iournie ſoone yeelde cauſe cleerer ſo worthily vertuouſly hee euery way beare himſelfe therein good hap euer accompanied encombrances difficulty hee ſubdue atchieuement noble enterpriſe ſeemed bee ſent god conſpiring ſecond conſenting favour juſtification man end excuſable euer could bee encreaſe profit repentance ſuperficiall meane ceremoious muſt touch mee ſides terme repentance muſt pinch entrailes afflict deepely throughly god himſelfe beholdes mee negotiating many good fortune haue ſlipt mee want good diſcretion yet proiects make good choyce according occurrence preſented vnto manner euer take eaſier ſurer ſide finde former deliberation proceeded rule diſcreetely ſubiects ſtate propounded mee like occaſions would proceede like hundred yeares hence reſpect conſulted conſequence deſſignes conſiſtes ſeaſons occaſions paſſe matter change vnceſſantlie time runne ſome groſſe abſurde important error want good aduiſe good happe ſecret indiuinable partes obiects men doe handle eſpeciallie nature men mute condition without ſhew ſometimes vnknowne poſſeſſours produced ſtirred vp ſuddaine occaſions wit coulde neyther finde preſage offended function thereof contained within owne limit ſucceſſe beate mee favour ſide refuſed noe remedy fall ſelfe accuſe fortune endeuour thats called repentance phocion giuen athenian ſome counſell followed matter againſt opinion ſucceeding happily phocion quoth one art thou pleaſed matter hath thriued ſo well yea ſaide hee glad yet repent aduiſe gaue friend come mee counſell beſtowe francklie clearelie well nigh worlde doth wavering hazard matter whereby contrary meaning may happen ſo may juſtly finde fault aduiſe care greatly ſhall doe mee wrong became mee refuſe dutie haue body blame faultes misfortune ſelfe effect ſeldome vſe aduiſe vnleſſe complement ſake haue need inſtruction knowledge fact marry thing wherin nought judgment bee employed ſtrange reaſons may ſerve ſuſtaine divert lende favourable curteous eare vnto remembrance never beleeued mine owne mee flyes moathes diſtract little regarde mine owne opinion men eſteeme little fortune paye mee accordingly take counſell give little much ſought leſſe credited give neither knowe enterpriſe either private publike aduiſe hath directed brought concluſion euen thoſe whome fortune ſomeway tyde therevnto willingly admitted direction others conceites mine one jealous right quiet thoſe authoritie would rather haue thus leaving iumpe profeſſion wholly ſettle containe mee ſelfe pleaſure vnto mee bee diſintereſſed men affayres diſingaged contention ſutes buſineſſes bee ouerpaſt howſoever bee greeve little imagination muſt neceſſarily happenſo put mee paine behould courſe vniuerſe enchained stoy call cauſes fantazie cannot wiſhe imagination remooue one point whole order thing muſt reverſe paſt come moreover hate accidentall repentance olde age bringes hee ancient time ſaid hee beholden yeares becauſe ridde voluptuouſneſſe mine opinion ſhall neuer giue impuiſſance thankes good doe mee nec tam averſa vnquam videbitur ab opere ſuo providentia vt debilitas inter optimum inuenta ſit ſhall foreſight euer bee ſeene ſo auerſe hir owne worke weakeneſſe bee found bee one best thing appetite rare oldeage blowe overpaſſed deepe ſacietie ſeazeth vpon v therein ſee conſcience fretting care weakeneſſe imprint v effeminate drowzie vertue wee muſt ſuffer ſelues ſo fully carried naturall alteration corrupt adulterate iudgement youth pleaſure haue heretofore prevailed ſo much ouer could ever even midſt ſenſualities diſcerne vgly face ſinne diſtaſte yeares bring inſtant keepe mee diſcerning voluptuouſneſſe vice longer judge ſtill lively attentively examine rangeth moderate fortifieth hath ſelfe awaken faculty nature given vnto matter owne advantage ſubiects fit enough whereon deviſe determine meditation large powerfull ſtudie ſuch vigorouſly taſte employ themſelues therein rather forge furniſh minde office occupation either weaker ſtronger entertaining one thought according minde whatſoever greateſt make vacation quibus viuere eſt cogitare one depending others one troubleſome tedious raritie withers old age could ſufficiently provided liues neceſſities bookes third much ſolidſure much ſome advantage yeeldeth two former hath ſhare conſtancie facilitie ſervice accoſteth ſecondeth courſe every aſſiſteth comfort mee age ſolaceth ſolitarineſſe eaſeth mee burden wearyſome ſloth time rids mee tedious company abateth edge fretting ſorrow condition bee extreme overinſolent divert importunate imagination inſinuating conceit better way recourſe vnto bookes eaſe allure mee facilitie remoove though perceive neither frequent ſeeke wanting eſſentiall lively naturall commodity never mutinie murmure mee ſtill entertaine mee one ſelfeſame viſage hee may well walke foot leades horſe bridle ſaith proverbe iames king naples sicilie faire licentious allurement employ minde wanton youthfull conceit wherein ſhe recreates hir ſelfe much ſetled heavy ripe yeares read daily leſſon coldneſſe temperance body ſhunneth diſorder feares hath affoord mee men intenta ſuis ne ſict vſque malisouid trist li 4 • 1 4 still let conceit attend il much offend gently turne aſide ſteale mine eies viewing tempeſtuous cloudy skie thankes god conſider maſters purſe yet hate beautie opportunitie deſtinie deſtinie hath alſo hand therein —fatum eſt partibus illis 〈…〉 〈…〉 9 32 quas ſinus abſcondit nam ſi tibi fideracaſſent n • l faciet longi menſura incognita nervi thoſe part fate hidden thou wroughtfor thy ſtarre meaſure long nerve vnknowne nothing ſerves entangled wo • ſtranger yet peradventure ſo abſolutely ſome bond may bee left hold husband hate ſlie monopoly cloſe conſpiracies notumque furens quid foemina poſſitvirg aen l 5 6 knowne woman may whoſe raging paſſions ſtay raging ſpight ſo much fretteth itſelfe forced excuſe ſelfe vnder pretence goodwill dutie chaſtitie hath large extenſion farrereaching compaſſe would bridle thats part pliable active nimble quickrolling ſtaied dreames doe ſometimes engage ſo farre cannot diſſemble deny lieth perhaps chaſtitie ſelfe ſeeing ſhe female ſhield themſelves concupiſcence avoid deſiring intereſſe engage v caſe imagine great throng men would bee purſuit priuilege wingedſpeed though raſhneſſe required youth excuſe vnder colour heat ſhould woman looke neerer vnto might finde rather proceedeth contempt ſuperſticiouſly feared offend love willingly reſpect beſides depriveth merchandize reverence defaceth luſter love man ſhould therein ſomewhat play childe daſtard ſervant altogether yet ſome thing ſome aire motif ſottiſh baſhfulneſſe whereof plutarch ſpeaketh courſe life hath diverſly beene wounded tainted qualitie ill beſeeming vniverſall forme amongst v ſedition • arring mine eies tender beare refuſall refuſe doth ſo much trouble troubleſome others occaſions force dutie compelleth trie one doubtfull thing coſt vnto doe faintly much againſt mine owne private buſineſle though homer ſay moſt truly indigent needy man baſhfulneſſe • ond vertue commonly ſubſtitute lewder bluſh allow yea commend abſtinence moſt brutiſh terme worke beaſtly begets maketh v moſt people haue concurred diuers cerimonies religion ſacrifices luminary faſtings incenſings offrings belonging ſhamful mine properly ſo inſtant eſſeniens plinte ſpeaketh maintained themſelues long time without nurces ſwathling clothes arriual ſtrangers came ſhoares ſeconding fond humor often viſit whole nation hazarding rather conſume engage themſelues feminine embracement rather looſe ſucceſſion men forge one report zeno neuer dealt woman life hee ciuilitie leaſt ſhould ouer obſtinately ſeeme contemne ſex one auoideth ſee man borne runne haſtily ſee dye deſtroy wee ſeeke ſpacious field full light conſtruct hide ſelues ſome darke corner worke cloſe may dutie conceale ſelues making glory diſplaide vnto declination vigor birth ſame fit deferring man cannot alwayes keepe even pace ever go alike haue bin ſo ſparing promiſe thinke paid either promiſed due found mee faithfull euen ſeruice might prooue vnto inſufficiency ſo • tiſhneſſe commendable diſcommendable action much ſeperate ſelfe humour ſo much approach vnto mine owne moreover neuer ſuffer ſelfe bee wholly given ſport therewith ingratitude treaſon malice cruelty bought pleaſure vice rate content owne ſimple coſt nullum intraſe vi • ium eſt vice contained ſelfe hate almoſt alike crouching dull laſineſſe toileſome thorny agitation neither troubled tormented heated diſtempred wee muſt make ſtay onely hurtfull vnto fooles young man demanded philoſopher panetius whether would ſeeme wiſe man loue let wiſemen alone quoth thee ſo beſt engage ſelues ſo ſtirring violent humor mak v ſlaves others contemptible vnto ſelues ſaid true ought entruſt matter ſo dangerous vnto mind hath wherwith ſuſtaine approach effectually quaile ſpeach ageſilaus wiſedome loue cannot liue together vaine occupation ti true vnſeemely ſhamefull lawleſſe vſing manner eſteeme wholſome fit rouze dull ſpi ••• heauy body phiſition experienced meaſure bee ioined therewith alloweth moderation ſhunning effort reſiſtance employed againſt ſtrange baſtard lawleſſe one ſaith bodyes appetite ought encreaſed minde wittily aduiſeth v ſhould excite hunger ſacietie ſtuffe inſteed filling belly auoide jouiſſance may bring v want ſhunne meat drink may make v hungry thirſtie ſeruice love ſhe appoints v take obiect onely may ſatisfie body neede
